name: electricity production, hydro, reservoir, alpine region | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21558/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity at grid-connected reservoir hydropower plants located in mountaineous regions in Argentina in 2014. Lifetime is assumed to be 150 years for the structural part and 80 years for the turbines. Net average electrical efficiency, including pipe losses, is 78% (best efficiency can be 84%).; It has been built based on the  "electricity production, hydro, reservoir, alpine region/GLO 2008" (accessed: February 2nd, 2018) See Modelling and administrative for more details.; "

This dataset starts from the power plant ready to produce electricity, i.e. the reservoir filled with water

This activity ends with 1kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. This dataset includes - the area/volume occupied for the barrage, power station, and the lake - a preliminary estimation of emissions of methane and dinitrogen oxide - operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants, such as lubricating oil or mass of water passing through the turbines. This dataset doesn't include - land use for access roads to the reservoir - emissions of carbon dioxide - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets - transformation of the electricity produced.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2014.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data were extrapolated from the average Swiss reservoir hydropower plant and adapted for Argentina
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Storage power plants have an appendant reservoir. The size of the reservoir can range from daily, monthly to annual storage reservoirs. According to the net head high-pressure, medium-pressure and low-pressure systems can be distinguished. High- and medium-pressure systems are constructed as dams. High-pressure storage power plants with a head of over 50 meters are very common in Switzerland (was considered the same for Argentina). For this dataset concrete dams (arch dams and gravity dams) with a height of more then 30 meters are taken into account. Also pumped storage power plants are included because in most cases the data is only available for the overall generation system. The same counts for high- and medium-pressure and alpine run-of-river power plants which are also included in the storage power plant dataset. Due to the fact that the efforts for the plant construction are similar to storage power plants and that the estimated production is comparatively low, high- and medium-pressure run-of-river power plants are covered by the reservoir power station dataset.;The technology used in the dataset has an overall efficiency of 82%, more modern technologies show an overall efficiency of about 88%. The overall efficiency is composed of the efficiency of the works water channel, the turbine, the generator and the transformer and are listed below:;;Efficiency of power plant               current    modern;Works water channel	        0.95	     0.95;Turbine	                                        0.87	     0.91;Generator	                                        0.96      0.98;Transformer	                        0.98	     0.99;Reservoir power plant total		;without works water channel           0.82	     0.88;with works water channel                0.78	     0.84;Pumped storage power plant        0.70	    0.74;;The losses along the works water channel are primarily caused by friction and are calculated from the difference between gross and net head. Based on this calculation the efficiency of the works water channel amounts to 95%. The losses depend on the flow rate and have its maximum at full load. The smaller the cross section of adits and pressure pipelines, the higher the flow velocity and thus the friction losses. In older plants according to Bischof (1992) the efficiency of works water channels could be increased generally more than by replacing turbines and generators.;;The efficiency losses in turbines depend on the turbine type (Kaplan, Francis, Pelton, etc.), the turbine output and on the ratio between turbined water amount and the rated water amount. In König (1997) examples for curve progressions of the relationship between these variables are shown. For current power plants an efficiency of 87% is assumed, more modern turbines show an efficiency of about 91%.;;The efficiency of generators depends on the output, the rotation speed of the generator and the cooling system. Some relevant data can be found in König (1997). For today’s power plants an efficiency of approximately 96% is assumed, modern generators show an efficiency of about 98%. The efficiency of transformers amounts to 98%, respectively 99%.;References:;Bischof, R. (1992) Modernisierungspotential bei bestehenden Wasserkraftwerken. Vortrag beim Schweizerischen Technischen Verband, Sektion Graubünden, 21. Oktober 1992. Churwalden, Schweiz [unpublished].;König F., von (1985) Bau von Wasserkraftanlagen. C.F. Müller, Karlsruhe.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
This dataset has been extrapolated from the "electricity production, hydro, reservoir, alpine region/GLO 2008" (accessed: February 2nd, 2018) dataset for reservoir power plants in alpine regions.. 
The information about annual electricity production and lakes area have been obtained for the Argentinean reservoirs in mountaineous regions. Other exchanges, such as the occupation area and the transformed to industrial area have been calculated on the basis of that information. Run-of-river with pondage power plants in non-alpine regions have been included in this dataset.
"methane non-fossil" emissions as well as the required amount of "lubricating oil" remain as in the original dataset, due to the lack of local data,
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Sampling procedure based on literature. Data referred to reservoir and run-of-riverr with pondage power plants in alpine regions. The considered power plants are Agua del Toro, Alicura, C.H.Cacheuta, Los Caracoles and Cuesta del Viento, Futaleufu, Nihuil 1, Nihuil 2, Nihuil 3, Nihuil 4, Pichi P. Leufu, Quebrada Ullum, Piedra D Aguila, This dataset has been built based on information from all these power plants. Representativeness is therefore 100 %

flow.name: electricity, high voltage
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

exchanges.description: Estimation. The area for the barrage and the power station are assumed to amount to 1% of the total land use. No land use for access roads was taken into account.

Estimation. The useful volume of all hydro power plants with pondage in mountain regions have been considered, and related with the amount of electricy produced during the useful life.
Source: Inventario de Presas y Centrales Hidroeléctricas de la República Argentina,- 1a ed. Subsecretaria de Recursos Hídricos de la Nación
Buenos Aires : Ministerio de Planificación Federal, Inversión Pública y Servicios, 2010. ISBN 978-987-23585-8-7

Estimation. The water surface of all hydro power plants with pondage in mountain regions have been summed up and divided by total annual average net generation of these plants and plant life time. Source: Inventario de Presas
y Centrales Hidroeléctricas de la República Argentina,- 1a ed. Subsecretaria de Recursos Hídricos de la Nación
Buenos Aires : Ministerio de Planificación Federal, Inversión Pública y Servicios, 2010. ISBN 978-987-23585-8-7

Literature/Estimation. 
It was assumed the emission factor used in the GLO 2008 dataset for alpine regions, which in turn is based on the emission factors calculated for the Swiss dataset.
The comment in the original dataset is as follows: 
Estimation. Total emissions of greenhouse gases are assumed to be 0.3 CO2equivalents per kWh. Research projects in Swiss natural lakes had measurements of 8-16 micromol per m2 and day (brutto emissions). Because of the limited rates of nitrification and denitrification, a maximum of 0.24 to 2.4 micromol per m2 and Tag can be assumed for Swiss reservoir plants.

flow.name: Dinitrogen monoxide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Reflects range average to best performance.

Estimation adopted ftom the global dataset "electricity production, hydro, reservoir, GLO, 2015":  Klimawirksamkeit. In: Gas - Wasser - Abwasser, 3/95 (1995), S. 224-234.
Gross methane emissions of natural Swiss lakes are assumed to amount to 40 kg/ha*y (Egger 1995). Further assumptions are the total area of Swiss reservoir plants (7000 ha) and the electricity production of those plants as an average of the years 1991-2000 (20'000 GWh/y).
It can be assumed the the actual methane emissions are lower than the resulting 0.014 g/kWh because of the high altitude of the reservoirs. There, only little biomass is flooded and the low temperatures constrain anaerobic degradation of the biomass.
Egger K.W. (1995) Methanemissionen der Schweiz und deren
Estimation. The emissions of methane are lower in alpine regions than in warmer regions. Total emissions of greenhouse gases are assumed to be 0.3 CO2equivalents per kWh. Methane emissions are a function of the flooded area, depth of the reservoir, flooded bimoass, surrounding temperature and climatic zone.

flow.name: Methane, non-fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature/calculation
This figure is calculated as the difference between the original transformed area and the estimation of the area occupied by the infrastructure of the power plant.

Literature value/calculated value. The needed amount of infrastructure per kWh produced is calculated with the lifetime and the annual net energy production (16500GWh/a). Value taken over from the corresponding global (GLO) dataset.

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Literature value/estimation. The specific turbine water amount is inversely proportional to the average  head. A guidance value says that a hydropower plant can produce 1kWh of electricity with 1 m3 water over a head of 450 m. WIth this information and the nominal head of each hydro power plant belonging to the "reservoir, alpine" type the turbine water amount has been calculated
Nominal Head Source: SRHN (2010). Inventario de presas y centrales de la República Argentina. - 1a ed. - Subsecretaria de Recursos Hídricos de la Nación. Buenos Aires: Ministerio de Planificación Federal, Inversión Pública y Servicios, 2010. ISBN 978-987-23585-8-7 Dirección Nacional de Conservación y Protección de los Recursos Hídricos


The ecological relevance of the turbine water amount is that it presents a demonstrative dimension of water being taken from natural water balance for a while.

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Data taken from the GLO 2008 dataset, estimated for a run-of-river power station. 
A consumption of lubricating oil for turbines of 9 liters per GWh is estimated. With an oil density of 0.84 kg/l this amounts to 0.007 g/kWh. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant.

There, a consumption of lubricating oil for turbines of 9 liters per GWh is estimated. With an oil density of 0.84 kg/l this amounts to 0.007 g/kWh. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant.
